data.title: Code editor does not scroll horizontally when using multiple carets
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:34:09.706Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
pgsql|dou|0.0.8
EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.4
JSDocTagComplete|Hoo|0.0.2
vscode-esformatter|how|1.5.2
output-colorizer|IBM|0.1.2
vscode-puglint|mrm|2.3.0
code-spell-checker|str|1.3.2



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a code editor where the width of the tab is smaller than the longest line of code.
2. Place multiple carets (2 is enough), one being on the longest line of code.
3. Mark to the end of the line, either by dragging horizontally or using keyboard shortcuts.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1658949/28823553-6891e8cc-76be-11e7-9173-163df2082e0c.gif)

data.title: Uri doesn't honour http-specialities
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: any

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create and MD file and paste the following link:
[https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/?ru=https%3A%2F%2Fmicrosoft.com%2F%3Fparam1%3Dvalue1%26param2%3Dvalue2](https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/?ru=https%3A%2F%2Fmicrosoft.com%2F%3Fparam1%3Dvalue1%26param2%3Dvalue2)

2. Preview and click on the link. You will be sent to https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/?ru=https://microsoft.com/%3Fparam1=value1&param2=value2

Notice that the url parameter `ru` is an encoded link. VSCode decodes the parameter and the final link becomes incorrect. Just compare to how GitHub works when you click on the link in step 1.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: flickering when fullscreen on Ubuntu Zesty + nvidia drivers

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version:
```
$ code --version
1.14.2
cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e
```
- OS Version:
```
$ lsb_release -a
No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID:	Ubuntu
Description:	Ubuntu 17.04
Release:	17.04
Codename:	zesty
```

- nVidia driver version:
```
$ cat /proc/driver/nvidia/version 
NVRM version: NVIDIA UNIX x86_64 Kernel Module  375.66  Mon May  1 15:29:16 PDT 2017
GCC version:  gcc version 6.3.0 20170406 (Ubuntu 6.3.0-12ubuntu2)
```

Steps to Reproduce:

0. Use nVidia graphics 
1. Launch code
2. Enter fullscreen (press f11)
3. Notice lots of flickering, especially when alt-tabbing between other programs with vscode running visibly in the background

Fortunately there is a perfect workaround, which is to launch with `--force-gpu-rasterization`

gnome users can edit the icon launcher
Edit `/usr/share/applications/code.desktop` and modify the two `Exec` lines to include the new flag:
```
[Desktop Entry]
Exec=/usr/share/code/code --force-gpu-rasterization --unity-launch %U
```
and
```
[Desktop Action new-window]
Exec=/usr/share/code/code --force-gpu-rasterization --new-window %U
```

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Task spinner doesn't go away when task is terminated
data.body:
Using tasks 2.0

- Start a long-running task that **isn't** marked as a "background" task
- Task spinner starts spinning in the status bar
- Terminate the task before it completes
- Spinner is still spinning until the window reloads

Regression from 1.14

data.title: Ampersands in context menu not displayed
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a command with ampersand in title
2. Create a context menu for the command (see example below)
3. Reload Code

**Example:**

```json
"commands": [
    {
        "command": "extension.nsis.compile",
        "title": "NSIS: Save & Compile Script"
    }
],
"menus": {
    "editor/context": [
        {
            "when": "resourceLangId == nsis",
            "command": "extension.nsis.compile"
        }
    ]
}
```

When opening the context-menu, the ampersand will not be displayed:

![vscode](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1504938/28800965-a8b85d38-764f-11e7-90ec-445ad3d2f498.png)

Somehow the regex were invalid and couldn't match anything?

However, I fixed them. Taking a deeper look, they were quite good, only the `else if` case was missing.

For @rebornix

data.title: Test TS Version Selector Changes for multiroot
data.body:
For #30262

**Size:** 2

**OS**: 
- [x] Linux @Tyriar 
- [x] Mac @ramya-rao-a 
- [x] Windows @aefernandes 

# Summary
The TypeScript version selector has been significantly refactored to support multiroot scenarios. More info about the new flow in second comment here: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/30262#issuecomment-317579332


# Test

**New folder**
1. Open an empty folder. Run `npm init -y`. Create an empty ts file
1. Verify version selector only have one option

**User Setting**
1. In your user settings, point `typescript.tsdk` to a global TS install using an absolute path
1. Confirm you still only have one entry in the selector
1. The server should now be using this version
1. Set `typescript.tsdk` to an invalid path. An error message should be shown and we should fallback to the bundled ts version

**Local TS**
1. Now run `npm install typescript`
1. Version selector should now have two entries
1. Confirm you can switch to the local version

**Local TSDK**
1. Set `typescript.tsdk` to `node_modules/typescript/lib`
1. Version selector should have two entries, one for VSCode's version and one for the local version
1. Try setting the user tsdk value to an invalid path. You should still see this in the selector but get an warning message when trying to use it

**Local TSDK using foldername**
1. Set local `typescript.tsdk` to `FOLDER_NAME/node_modules/typescript/lib`
1. confirm forms of this syntax work as expected.

**Workspace TSDK setting**
1. Convert folder into a workspace.
1. Ensure  workspace level setting of `typescript.tsdk` to `FOLDER_NAME/node_modules/typescript/lib` works
1. Add more folders to the workspace and try pointing at TS installs in them

**Workspace npm versions**
1. In a workspace with multiple folders
1. Remove all local `typescript.tsdk` setting values
1. Make sure typescript is installed under `node_modules` in several of the folders
1. The version selector should now show entries for each of these. 
1. Selecting one should update the workspace `typescript.tsdk` setting

data.title: Test: Terminal Quick Pick
data.body:
Covers https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/29879
- [x] Windows @mjbvz 
- [x] Linux @chrisdias 
- [x] Mac @kieferrm 

Complexity: 1
- Try executing `Terminal: Switch Active Terminal` from the command palette with: no terminals open, a few terminals open, and renamed terminals and tasks open.
- Do the same thing but from a keybinding for the command (as well as keybindings for quickOpenNavigate(Next|Previous)InTerminalPicker). You'll have to set the keybindings yourself as there is no default keybinding.
- Rename some terminals through the gear icon on the right. Verify that after renaming, you get taken back to the list of terminals.

data.title: Deprecating old emmet
data.body:
With this PR, we deprecate old emmet.

All Emmet actions have been moved to the Emmet extension.

`Expand Abbreviation` and `Wrap with Abbreviation` still go through the core so that languages whose parent are html as well as embedded languages get these 2 commands working out of the box. Eg: handlebars, php or vue

Once scope information is available to extensions, this can be skipped.

data.title: [Important] Microsoft Visual C++ Runtime Library: "Assertion failed" when closing a terminal process
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.15.0-insider (0e7546c978fa1b62dbf36f07a77d1b9a4241d6f7, 2017-07-28T11:23:06.089Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
Bookmarks|ale|0.15.2
npm-intellisense|chr|1.3.0
path-intellisense|chr|1.4.2
regex|chr|0.1.0

composer|ika|0.5.0

code-guid|jam|1.0.1
StretchTimer|jpa|0.0.1
json-to-ts|Mar|1.5.2
Runner|mat|0.1.14
vscode-apache|mrm|1.1.1
cpptools|ms-|0.12.1
github-issues-prs|ms-|0.3.1
php-docblocker|nei|1.2.0
emoji|Per|0.0.3
vscode-versionlens|pfl|0.19.1
datetime|rid|1.0.5
vscode-icons|rob|7.12.0
sharecode|Rol|0.4.1
todotasks|san|0.5.0
code-settings-sync|Sha|2.8.2
vscode-spotify|shy|2.0.0
packagelinker|sin|0.0.3
code-spell-checker|str|1.3.2
pdf|tom|0.2.0
lorem-ipsum|Tyr|1.0.0
vscode-arduino|vsc|0.2.4
vscode-todo-highlight|way|0.5.8
highlight-trailing-white-spaces|yba|0.0.2

(2 theme extensions excluded)


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open up an empty folder on windows. 
2. Open up an terminal.
3. Kill that terminal process.
4. Get this error message:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11234139/28799313-5fcbdab6-7648-11e7-89cf-88ac59235c07.png)


This issue is quite annoying, because it also reproduces when changing the current folder... :/ Most likely, this is upstream, but still important.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes **!!!**

I think you need more details, but which ones?

data.body: To align with other command palette names.
